title: Achan's Sin and Israel's Defeat
shortSummary: Joshua 7 recounts Israel’s defeat at Ai due to Achan’s disobedience in taking accursed items from Jericho. The chapter highlights the seriousness of sin within the community and the necessity of holiness for God’s blessing and victory. It serves as a sobering reminder of corporate responsibility and the consequences of hidden sin.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Conquest of Canaan under Joshua

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: Leader of Israel who commands the people and seeks God’s guidance after Israel’s defeat.

keyCharacters.name: Achan
keyCharacters.description: A member of the tribe of Judah who disobeys God by taking forbidden spoils, causing Israel’s defeat.

keyCharacters.name: Elders of Israel
keyCharacters.description: Senior leaders who join Joshua in mourning and seeking God’s direction.

definitions.definition: Objects or persons devoted to God for destruction, forbidden to be taken or kept by the Israelites.
To set apart as holy, purifying oneself from sin and impurity before God.
A location near Ai where the defeated Israelites were pursued and struck down.
The place where Achan and his possessions were destroyed; its name means 'valley of trouble,' symbolizing judgment.

outline.heading: Israel’s Sin and Defeat at Ai
outline.description: Israel is defeated at Ai because of Achan’s sin in taking forbidden spoils, which provokes God’s anger and causes the people to flee and lose heart.

outline.heading: Joshua’s Prayer and God’s Revelation
outline.description: Joshua mourns before God and questions the defeat; God reveals Israel’s sin and commands the removal of the accursed thing to restore His favor.

outline.heading: Identification of the Guilty Party
outline.description: Through a process of tribal, family, and individual selection, Achan is identified as the one who took the forbidden items and confesses his sin.

outline.heading: Judgment on Achan and Restoration
outline.description: Achan and his possessions are destroyed by stoning and fire, and the place is named the Valley of Achor; God’s anger turns away, signifying restored fellowship.

application: Confess and remove hidden sin promptly to avoid spiritual defeat and maintain fellowship with God.
Recognize that sin affects not only the individual but the entire community of believers.
Seek God earnestly in times of trouble through prayer and humility before Him.
Obey God’s commands fully, trusting His instructions lead to blessing and victory.

keyVerses.text: But the children of Israel committed a trespass in the accursed thing: for Achan, the son of Carmi, the son of Zabdi, the son of Zerah, of the tribe of Judah, took of the accursed thing: and the anger of the LORD was kindled against the children of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces the root cause of Israel’s defeat—Achan’s sin—and God’s resulting anger.

keyVerses.text: Israel hath sinned, and they have also transgressed my covenant which I commanded them: for they have even taken of the accursed thing, and have also stolen, and dissembled also, and they have put it even among their own stuff.
keyVerses.significance: God reveals Israel’s sin and covenant violation, emphasizing the seriousness of disobedience and deceit.

keyVerses.text: Up, sanctify the people, and say, Sanctify yourselves against to morrow: for thus saith the LORD God of Israel, There is an accursed thing in the midst of thee, O Israel: thou canst not stand before thine enemies, until ye take away the accursed thing from among you.
keyVerses.significance: God commands purification and removal of sin as a prerequisite for victory, underscoring holiness.

keyVerses.text: And Joshua said, Why hast thou troubled us? the LORD shall trouble thee this day. And all Israel stoned him with stones, and burned them with fire, after they had stoned them with stones.
keyVerses.significance: The judgment on Achan demonstrates the consequences of sin and the need for justice to restore God’s favor.
